protocol.title: QSAR for mutagenicity (Salmonella typhimurium TA98 strain)
protocol.abstract:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE QMRF SYSTEM "/WEB-INF/xslt/qmrf.dtd"> <QMRF author="European Chemicals Bureau" contact="Joint Research Centre, European Commission" date="July 2007" email="qsardb@jrc.it" name="(Q)SAR Model Reporting Format" schema_version="0.9" url="http://ecb.jrc.it/QSAR/" version="1.2"> <QMRF_chapters> <QSAR_identifier chapter="1" help="" name="QSAR identifier"> <QSAR_title chapter="1.1" help="" name="QSAR identifier (title)"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> QSAR for mutagenicity (Salmonella typhimurium TA98 strain) </p> </body></html></QSAR_title> <QSAR_models chapter="1.2" help="" name="Other related models"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Same endpoint and dataset as present model: </p> <p style="margin-top: 0">  </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Cash GG, Anderson B, Mayo K, Bogaczyk S &amp; Tunkel J (2005). Mutation  Research/Genetic Toxicology and Environmental Mutagenesis 585, 170-183. </p> </body></html></QSAR_models> <QSAR_software chapter="1.3" help="" name="Software coding the model">
<software_ref idref="firstsoftware" catalog="software_catalog"/> </QSAR_software> </QSAR_identifier> <QSAR_General_information chapter="2" help="" name="General information"> <qmrf_date chapter="2.1" help="" name="Date of QMRF"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 10.05.2009 </p> </body></html></qmrf_date> <qmrf_authors chapter="2.2" help="" name="QMRF author(s) and contact details">
<author_ref idref="firstauthor" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_3" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_4" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_5" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_6" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_7" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_8" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_9" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_10" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_11" catalog="authors_catalog"/> <author_ref idref="authors_catalog_12" catalog="authors_catalog"/> </qmrf_authors> <qmrf_date_revision chapter="2.3" help="" name="Date of QMRF update(s)"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0">  </p> </body></html></qmrf_date_revision> <qmrf_revision chapter="2.4" help="" name="QMRF update(s)"/> <model_authors chapter="2.5" help="" name="Model developer(s) and contact details">
<author_ref idref="modelauthor" catalog="authors_catalog"/> </model_authors> <model_date chapter="2.6" help="" name="Date of model development and/or publication"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 24.10.2008 </p> </body></html></model_date> <references chapter="2.7" help="" name="Reference(s) to main scientific papers and/or software package">
<publication_ref idref="publications_catalog_3" number="" catalog="publications_catalog"/> <publication_ref idref="publications_catalog_4" number="" catalog="publications_catalog"/> </references> <info_availability chapter="2.8" help="" name="Availability of information about the model"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Model is proprietary, but the training and test sets are available. </p> </body></html></info_availability> <related_models chapter="2.9" help="" name="Availability of another QMRF for exactly the same model"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> None to date </p> </body></html></related_models> </QSAR_General_information> <QSAR_Endpoint chapter="3" help="" name="Defining the endpoint - OECD Principle 1"> <model_species chapter="3.1" help="" name="Species"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Salmonella typhimurium (TA98 strain) </p> </body></html></model_species> <model_endpoint chapter="3.2" help="" name="Endpoint">
<endpoint_ref idref="endpoints_catalog_5" catalog="endpoints_catalog"/> </model_endpoint> <endpoint_comments chapter="3.3" help="" name="Comment on endpoint"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Mutagenicity, measured on Salmonella typhimurium TA98 with the addition  of an exogenous metabolic activation system (S9). </p> </body></html></endpoint_comments> <endpoint_units chapter="3.4" help="" name="Endpoint units"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> log(reversions/nmol), log of the number of reversions per nanomole of  substance </p> </body></html></endpoint_units> <endpoint_variable chapter="3.5" help="" name="Dependent variable"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> log(reversions/nmol), logR </p> </body></html></endpoint_variable> <endpoint_protocol chapter="3.6" help="" name="Experimental protocol"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Mutagenicity: reverse mutation test using bacteria was carried out  according to the OECD 471 (EU B.13/14) test guideline. The bacterial  reversed mutation assay (Ames Test) is used to detect point mutations,  which involve substitution, addition or deletion of one or a few DNA  base pairs. The test uses bacterial culture of amino acid-dependent  strain of Salmonella typhimurium (TA98 or TA100), which is exposed to  the test substance in the presence and in the absence of an exogenous  metabolic activation system [cofactor-supplemented post-mitochondrial  fraction (S9) prepared from the liver]. Mutagenic compounds cause an  increase in the number of revertant colonies relative to the background  level. The mutagenic potencies of tested substances are expressed as  log(revertants/nmol). For non-mutagenic compounds, the potency is  arbitrarily coded as - 100. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> The test substances were with a high purity grade: 99.9% or higher.  Solid test substances were dissolved or suspended in appropriate  solvents and diluted if appropriate prior to treatment of the bacteria.  Liquid test substances were added directly to the test systems and/or  diluted prior to treatment. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0">  </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> References (related to experimental protocol): </p> <p style="margin-top: 0">  </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 1) Debnath AK, Debnath G,Shusterman AJ &amp; Hansch C (1992). A QSAR  investigation of the role of hydrophobicity in regulating mutagenicity  in the Ames test, Part 1: Mutagenicity of aromatic and heteroaromatic  amines in Salmonella typhimurium TA98 and TA100. Environmental and  Molecular Mutagenesis 19, 37&#8211;52. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 2) Glende C, Schmitt H, Erdinger L, Engelhardt G &amp; Boche G  (2001).Transformation of mutagenic aromatic amines into non-mutagenic  species by alkyl substituents. I. Alkylation ortho to the amino  function. Mutation Research 498, 19&#8211;37. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 3) Glende C, Klein M, Schmitt H, Erdinger L &amp; Boche G (2002).  Transformation of mutagenic aromatic amines into non-mutagenic species  by alkyl substituents. II. Alkylation far away from the amino function.  Mutation Research 515, 15-38. </p> </body></html></endpoint_protocol> <endpoint_data_quality chapter="3.7" help="" name="Endpoint data quality and variability"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Experimental data from different sources have been used. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Statistics: </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> max value: 3.97 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> min value: -3.32 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> standard deviation: 1.78 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> skewness: 0.44 </p> </body></html></endpoint_data_quality> </QSAR_Endpoint> <QSAR_Algorithm chapter="4" help="" name="Defining the algorithm - OECD Principle 2"> <algorithm_type chapter="4.1" help="" name="Type of model"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> QSAR </p> </body></html></algorithm_type> <algorithm_explicit chapter="4.2" help="" name="Explicit algorithm"> <algorithm_ref idref="algorithms_catalog_3" catalog="algorithms_catalog"/> <equation><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> log(reversions/nmol) = -8.03 + 1.45* Average Information content (order  2) + 0.475*Number of aromatic bonds - 0.0837* Shadow plane YZ (AM1) </p> </body></html></equation> </algorithm_explicit> <algorithms_descriptors chapter="4.3" help="" name="Descriptors in the model">
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_1" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/> <descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_2" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/> <descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_3" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/> </algorithms_descriptors> <descriptors_selection chapter="4.4" help="" name="Descriptor selection"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Initial pool of ~1000 descriptors. Stepwise descriptor selection based  on a set of statistical selection rules (one-parameter equations: Fisher  criterion and R2 over threshold, variance and t-test value over  threshold, intercorrelation with another descriptor not over threshold), </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> (two-parameter equations: intercorrelation coefficient below threshold,  significant correlation with endpoint, in terms of correlation  coefficient and t-test) </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Stepwise trial of additional descriptors not significantly correlated to  any already in the model. </p> </body></html></descriptors_selection> <descriptors_generation chapter="4.5" help="" name="Algorithm and descriptor generation"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 1D, 2D, and 3D theoretical calculations. Quantum chemical descriptors  derived from MMFFs (Merck Molecular Force Field) (vacuum) conformational  search and AM1 calculation. Model developed by using multilinear  regression. </p> </body></html></descriptors_generation> <descriptors_generation_software chapter="4.6" help="" name="Software name and version for descriptor generation" options="">
<software_ref idref="software_catalog_2" catalog="software_catalog"/> </descriptors_generation_software> <descriptors_chemicals_ratio chapter="4.7" help="" name="Descriptors/Chemicals ratio"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 31.0 (93 chemicals/3 descriptors)  </p> </body></html></descriptors_chemicals_ratio> </QSAR_Algorithm> <QSAR_Applicability_domain chapter="5" help="" name="Defining the applicability domain - OECD Principle 3"> <app_domain_description chapter="5.1" help="" name="Description of the applicability domain of the model"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Applicability domain based on training set: </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> a) by chemical identity: aromatic and heteroaromatic amines </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> b) by descriptor value range: The model is suitable for compounds that  have the descriptors </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> in the following range: </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Average Information content (order 2): 1.84 - 5.36 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Number of aromatic bonds: 4.2 - 27.3 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Shadow plane YZ (AM1): 12.4 - 65.0 </p> </body></html></app_domain_description> <app_domain_method chapter="5.2" help="" name="Method used to assess the applicability domain"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Presence of functional groups in structures (amino groups and aromatic  moieties) </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Range of descriptor values in training set with &#177;30% confidence.  Descriptor values must fall between maximal and minimal descriptor  values of training set &#177;30%. </p> </body></html></app_domain_method> <app_domain_software chapter="5.3" help="" name="Software name and version for applicability domain assessment">
<software_ref idref="software_catalog_3" catalog="software_catalog"/> </app_domain_software> <applicability_limits chapter="5.4" help="" name="Limits of applicability"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> See 5.1 </p> </body></html></applicability_limits> </QSAR_Applicability_domain> <QSAR_Robustness chapter="6" help="" name="Internal validation - OECD Principle 4"> <training_set_availability answer="Yes" chapter="6.1" help="" name="Availability of the training set"/> <training_set_data cas="Yes" chapter="6.2" chemname="Yes" formula="Yes" help="" inchi="No" mol="Yes" name="Available information for the training set" smiles="No"/> <training_set_descriptors answer="All" chapter="6.3" help="" name="Data for each descriptor variable for the training set"/> <dependent_var_availability answer="All" chapter="6.4" help="" name="Data for the dependent variable for the training set"/> <other_info chapter="6.5" help="" name="Other information about the training set"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 93 data points  </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 53 negative values  </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 40 positive values </p> </body></html></other_info> <preprocessing chapter="6.6" help="" name="Pre-processing of data before modelling"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> n/a </p> </body></html></preprocessing> <goodness_of_fit chapter="6.7" help="" name="Statistics for goodness-of-fit"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> R2 = 0.722 (Correlation coefficient); </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> s = 0.906 (Standard error of the estimate); </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> F = 77.1 (Fisher function); </p> </body></html></goodness_of_fit> <loo chapter="6.8" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by leave-one-out cross-validation"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> R2cv = 0.692 (Cross-validated correlation coefficient); </p> </body></html></loo> <lmo chapter="6.9" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by leave-many-out cross-validation"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> R2cv= 0.683  </p> </body></html></lmo> <yscrambling chapter="6.10" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by Y-scrambling"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> n/a </p> </body></html></yscrambling> <bootstrap chapter="6.11" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by bootstrap"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> n/a </p> </body></html></bootstrap> <other_statistics chapter="6.12" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by other methods"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> ABC analysis (2:1 training : prediction) on sorted (in increased order  of endpoint value) data divided into 3 subsets (A;B;C). Training set  formed with 2/3 of the compounds (set A+B, A+C, B+C) and validation set  consisted of 1/3 of the compounds (C, B, A). </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> average R2 (fitting) = 0.731 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> average R2 (prediction) = 0.698 </p> </body></html></other_statistics> </QSAR_Robustness> <QSAR_Predictivity chapter="7" help="" name="External validation - OECD Principle 4"> <validation_set_availability answer="Yes" chapter="7.1" help="" name="Availability of the external validation set"/> <validation_set_data cas="Yes" chapter="7.2" chemname="Yes" formula="Yes" help="" inchi="No" mol="Yes" name="Available information for the external validation set" smiles="No"/> <validation_set_descriptors answer="All" chapter="7.3" help="" name="Data for each descriptor variable for the external validation set"/> <validation_dependent_var_availability answer="All" chapter="7.4" help="" name="Data for the dependent variable for the external validation set"/> <validation_other_info chapter="7.5" help="" name="Other information about the external validation set"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> 31 data points: 17 negative values, 14 positive values </p> </body></html></validation_other_info> <experimental_design chapter="7.6" help="" name="Experimental design of test set"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> From sorted data of the initial set (by endpoint value) each 4th was  subjected to test set, starting from 3rd data point, the rest composing  the training set. </p> </body></html></experimental_design> <validation_predictivity chapter="7.7" help="" name="Predictivity - Statistics obtained by external validation"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> R2 = 0.647 (Correlation coefficient) </p> </body></html></validation_predictivity> <validation_assessment chapter="7.8" help="" name="Predictivity - Assessment of the external validation set"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Descriptor value range (all in range of applicability domain): </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Average Information content (order 2): 2.61 - 3.72 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Number of aromatic bonds: 6 - 19 </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Shadow plane YZ (AM1): 18.0 - 44.0 </p> </body></html></validation_assessment> <validation_comments chapter="7.9" help="" name="Comments on the external validation of the model"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Correlation coefficient value of test set close to that of the training  set. </p> </body></html></validation_comments> </QSAR_Predictivity> <QSAR_Interpretation chapter="8" help="" name="Providing a mechanistic interpretation - OECD Principle 5"> <mechanistic_basis chapter="8.1" help="" name="Mechanistic basis of the model"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> &#8220;Average Information content (order 2)&#8221; shows how information rich is  the molecule. It shows the branching of the molecule and simultaneously  takes into account also different atom types, hence different  electonegativities. &#8220;Number of aromatic bonds&#8221; counts all aromatic bonds  in the molecule. &#8220;Shadow plane YZ (AM1)&#8221; reflects to the thickness of  the molecule. </p> <p style="margin-top: 0"> &#8220;Average Information content (order 2)&#8221; and &#8220;Number of aromatic bonds&#8221;  are favorable descriptors, higher descriptor value leads to higher  property value. Conversely &#8220;Shadow plane YZ (AM1)&#8221; is unfavorable to the  property. </p> </body></html></mechanistic_basis> <mechanistic_basis_comments chapter="8.2" help="" name="A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretation"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> a posteriori mechanistic interpretation, consistent with published  scientific interpretations of experiments (no logP/hydrophobicity  dependence has been observed, same as in literature, importance of  configuration and conformation of the molecule and other structural  features, as described by the information content and shadow area  descriptors. Importance of the amount of aromatic moieties, as  described by the number of aromatic bonds descriptor. However, no  HOMO/LUMO dependence observes, as some literature sources suggest. </p> </body></html></mechanistic_basis_comments> <mechanistic_basis_info chapter="8.3" help="" name="Other information about the mechanistic interpretation"><html> <head> </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Interpretation in general agreement with literature: Benigni R.  Structure-activity relationship studies of chemical mutagens and  carcinogens: Mechanistic investigations and prediction approaches. Chem  Rev 105:1767&#8211;1800 (2005) </p> </body></html></mechanistic_basis_info> </QSAR_Interpretation> <QSAR_Miscelaneous chapter="9" help="" name="Miscellaneous information"> <comments chapter="9.1" help="" name="Comments"><html> <head>  </head> <body> <p style="margin-top: 0"> Experimental data is taken from Cash et al (2005). </p> </body></html></comments> <bibliography chapter="9.2" help="" name="Bibliography">

<QSAR_Endpoint chapter="3" help="" name="Defining the endpoint - OECD Principle 1">
<model_species chapter="3.1" help="" name="Species"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honey bee
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</model_species>
<model_endpoint chapter="3.2" help="" name="Endpoint">      


<endpoint_ref idref="endpoints_catalog_4" catalog="endpoints_catalog"/>
</model_endpoint>
<endpoint_comments chapter="3.3" help="" name="Comment on endpoint"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honey bee acute contact toxicity.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_comments>
<endpoint_units chapter="3.4" help="" name="Endpoint units"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      log(umol/org)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_units>
<endpoint_variable chapter="3.5" help="" name="Dependent variable"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      log(LD50)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_variable>
<endpoint_protocol chapter="3.6" help="" name="Experimental protocol"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honey bee acute contact toxicity was determined using the OECD Test 
      Guideline 214 (EU C.17). The acute contact toxicity test is carried out 
      to determine the inherent toxicity of pesticides and other chemicals to 
      bees. Acute contact toxicity is presented as the median lethal dose 
      (LD50) at which half of the population of honeybee died after exposure 
      for 48 h.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_protocol>
<endpoint_data_quality chapter="3.7" help="" name="Endpoint data quality and variability"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Toxicity data in EPA Office of Pesticide Programs database 
      (http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/) are drawn from several sources and then 
      reviewed:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (i) Ecotoxicological studies conducted by commercial laboratories and 
      submitted by pesticide companies in support of their products. EPA's 
      Office of Compliance and Monitoring conducts periodic audits of these 
      laboratories.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (ii) Studies conducted by US-EPA, USDA, and USFWS laboratories over the 
      last 25 years.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (iii) Published data considered to meet their guideline criteria for 
      acceptable data.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Inorganic compounds and mixtures in which components have different 
      molecular weight or connectivity (i.e., substances with different 
      chemical identity) were eliminated from the original EPA dataset. 
      However, mixtures of stereoisomers were kept, because they are super 
      imposable using common 2D descriptors. Data for LC50 48 h exposure of 
      honeybee were then pruned as follows:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (i) Eliminating studies with an a.s.&lt;85% purity.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (ii) Those identified as invalid where invalid studies were defined by 
      the EPA as studies which may not be scientifically sound, or they were 
      performed under conditions that deviated so significantly from the 
      recommended protocols that the results will not be useful in a risk 
      assessment.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (iii) Furthermore, only studies with actual values were kept discarding 
      data given as higher or lower that values.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Statistics:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      max value: 0.11
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      min value: -4.26
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      standard deviation: 1.33
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      skewness: -0.69
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_data_quality>
</QSAR_Endpoint>
<QSAR_Algorithm chapter="4" help="" name="Defining the algorithm - OECD Principle 2">
<algorithm_type chapter="4.1" help="" name="Type of model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      QSAR
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</algorithm_type>
<algorithm_explicit chapter="4.2" help="" name="Explicit algorithm">
<algorithm_ref idref="algorithms_catalog_1" catalog="algorithms_catalog"/>
<equation><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Log(LD50)= -136 -0.548 Highest total interaction (AM1) for C - C bonds 
      +11.0*Min atomic orbital electronic population (AM1) -4.00*ZX Shadow / 
      ZX Rectangle (AM1) -0.315*Highest e-n attraction (AM1) for C - O bonds
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</equation>
</algorithm_explicit>
<algorithms_descriptors chapter="4.3" help="" name="Descriptors in the model">            











<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_1" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_2" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_3" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_4" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
</algorithms_descriptors>
<descriptors_selection chapter="4.4" help="" name="Descriptor selection"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Initial pool of ~1000 descriptors. Stepwise descriptor selection based 
      on a set of statistical selection rules:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1-parameter equations: Fisher criterion and R2 over threshold, variance 
      and t-test value over threshold, intercorrelation with another 
      descriptor not over threshold.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      2 parameter equations: intercorrelation coefficient below threshold, 
      significant correlation with endpoint, in terms of correlation 
      coefficient and t-test.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Stepwise trial of additional descriptors not significantly correlated to 
      any already in the model.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_selection>
<descriptors_generation chapter="4.5" help="" name="Algorithm and descriptor generation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1D, 2D, and 3D theoretical calculations.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Quantum chemical descriptors were derived from Merck Molecular Force 
      Field (MMFFs) (water) conformational search and AM1 calculation. Model 
      developed by using multilinear regression
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_generation>
<descriptors_generation_software chapter="4.6" help="" name="Software name and version for descriptor generation" options="">				      


<software_ref idref="software_catalog_2" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</descriptors_generation_software>
<descriptors_chemicals_ratio chapter="4.7" help="" name="Descriptors/Chemicals ratio"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      11.8 (47 chemicals/4 descriptors)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_chemicals_ratio>
</QSAR_Algorithm>
<QSAR_Applicability_domain chapter="5" help="" name="Defining the applicability domain - OECD Principle 3">
<app_domain_description chapter="5.1" help="" name="Description of the applicability domain of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Applicability domain based on training set:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      a) by chemical identity: pesticides with ester functionality
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      b) by descriptor value range:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Highest total interaction (AM1) for C - C bonds (min: -15.9, max:-11.9)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Min atomic orbital electronic population (AM1) (min: 0.48, max: 0.81)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      ZX Shadow / ZX Rectangle (AM1) (min: 0.49, max:0.78)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Highest e-n attraction (AM1) for C - O bonds (min: -393, max: -381)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_description>
<app_domain_method chapter="5.2" help="" name="Method used to assess the applicability domain"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Pesticides with presence of ester functional groups in the structures
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Range of descriptor values in training set with &#177;30% confidence
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Descriptor values must fall between maximal and minimal descriptor 
      values of training set &#177;30%.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_method>
<app_domain_software chapter="5.3" help="" name="Software name and version for applicability domain assessment">      


<software_ref idref="software_catalog_3" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</app_domain_software>
<applicability_limits chapter="5.4" help="" name="Limits of applicability"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Compounds should contain the ester functional group.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</applicability_limits>
</QSAR_Applicability_domain>

<other_statistics chapter="6.12" help="" name="Robustness - Statistics obtained by other methods"><html>

    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      ABC analysis (2:1 training : prediction) on sorted data divided into 3

      A+C, B+C) and validation set consisted of 1/3 of the

    </p>

      average R<sup>2</sup> (fitting) = 0.83

<QSAR_Interpretation chapter="8" help="" name="Providing a mechanistic interpretation - OECD Principle 5">
<mechanistic_basis chapter="8.1" help="" name="Mechanistic basis of the model"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      ZX Shadow / ZX Rectangle (AM1) descriptor reflects how well is the 
      compound packed in its length and height dimension. The descriptor is 
      related to geometrical shape of the molecule. It describes not only on 
      the conformation but also the orientation of the molecule. 
      Quantum-chemical energy descriptors Highest total interaction (AM1) for 
      C - C bonds and Highest e-n attraction (AM1) for C - O bonds are related 
      to the stability/activity of the esters. Higher interaction energies in 
      absolute scale (the values are negative) show higher stability of the 
      compounds, and thus, they lead to lower toxicity, hence the negative 
      sign in the model. Min atomic orbital electronic population (AM1) is 
      related to electrophilicity. Lower values lead to higher toxicity 
      because the compound forms stronger electrophilic interactions.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis>
<mechanistic_basis_comments chapter="8.2" help="" name="A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      A priori - it was postulated that amines have different mechanism than 
      other compounds. The rest of the interpretation &#8211; a posteriori.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_comments>
<mechanistic_basis_info chapter="8.3" help="" name="Other information about the mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_info>
</QSAR_Interpretation>

      on bees is an important ecologic question.
    </p>
  </body>

<QSAR_Endpoint chapter="3" help="" name="Defining the endpoint - OECD Principle 1">
<model_species chapter="3.1" help="" name="Species"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honey bee
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</model_species>
<model_endpoint chapter="3.2" help="" name="Endpoint">      




<endpoint_ref idref="endpoints_catalog_4" catalog="endpoints_catalog"/>
</model_endpoint>
<endpoint_comments chapter="3.3" help="" name="Comment on endpoint"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honey bee acute contact toxicity.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_comments>
<endpoint_units chapter="3.4" help="" name="Endpoint units"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      log(&#956;mol/org)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_units>
<endpoint_variable chapter="3.5" help="" name="Dependent variable"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
       log(LD50)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_variable>
<endpoint_protocol chapter="3.6" help="" name="Experimental protocol"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Honeybee acute contact toxicity was determined using the OECD Test 
      Guideline 214 (EU C.17). The acute contact toxicity test is carried out 
      to determine the inherent toxicity of pesticides and other chemicals to 
      bees. Acute contact toxicity is presented as the median lethal dose 
      (LD50) at which half of the population of honeybee died after exposure 
      for 48 h.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_protocol>
<endpoint_data_quality chapter="3.7" help="" name="Endpoint data quality and variability"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Toxicity data for EPA - Office of Pesticide Programs database 
      (http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/) are drawn from several sources and then 
      reviewed:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (i) Ecotoxicological studies conducted by commercial laboratories and 
      submitted by pesticide companies in support of their products. EPA's 
      Office of Compliance and Monitoring conducts periodic audits of these 
      laboratories.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (ii) Studies conducted by US-EPA, USDA, and USFWS laboratories over the 
      last 25 years.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (iii) Published data considered to meet their guideline criteria for 
      acceptable data.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Inorganic compounds and mixtures in which components have different 
      molecular weight or connectivity (i.e., substances with different 
      chemical identity) were eliminated from the original EPA dataset. 
      However, mixtures of stereoisomers were kept, because they are 
      super-imposable using common 2D descriptors. Data for LC50 48 h exposure 
      of honeybee were then pruned as follows:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (i) Eliminating studies with an a.s.&lt;85% purity.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (ii) Those identified as invalid where invalid studies were defined by 
      the EPA as studies which may not be scientifically sound, or they were 
      performed under conditions that deviated so significantly from the 
      recommended protocols that the results will not be useful in a risk 
      assessment.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (iii) Furthermore, only studies with actual values were kept discarding 
      data given as higher or lower that values.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Statistics:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      max value: 0.54
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      min value: -4.16
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      standard deviation: 1.05
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      skewness: -1.47
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_data_quality>
</QSAR_Endpoint>
<QSAR_Algorithm chapter="4" help="" name="Defining the algorithm - OECD Principle 2">
<algorithm_type chapter="4.1" help="" name="Type of model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      QSAR
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</algorithm_type>
<algorithm_explicit chapter="4.2" help="" name="Explicit algorithm">
<algorithm_ref idref="algorithms_catalog_1" catalog="algorithms_catalog"/>
<equation><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Log(LD50)= 1.33 -35.4 Max electrophilic reactivity index (AM1) -0.214* 
      RNCS Relative negative charged SA (SAMNEG*RNCG) (AM1) -4.17E-4* Reverse 
      Wiener index
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</equation>
</algorithm_explicit>
<algorithms_descriptors chapter="4.3" help="" name="Descriptors in the model">            














<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_1" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_2" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_3" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
</algorithms_descriptors>
<descriptors_selection chapter="4.4" help="" name="Descriptor selection"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Initial pool of ~1000 descriptors. Stepwise descriptor selection based 
      on a set of statistical selection rules:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1-parameter equations: Fisher criterion and R2 over threshold, variance 
      and t-test value over threshold, intercorrelation with another 
      descriptor not over threshold.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      2 parameter equations: intercorrelation coefficient below threshold, 
      significant correlation with endpoint, in terms of correlation 
      coefficient and t-test.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Stepwise trial of additional descriptors not significantly correlated to 
      any already in the model.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_selection>
<descriptors_generation chapter="4.5" help="" name="Algorithm and descriptor generation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1D, 2D, and 3D theoretical calculations.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Quantum chemical descriptors were derived from Merck Molecular Force 
      Field (MMFFs) (water) conformational search and AM1 calculation. Model 
      developed by using multilinear regression.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_generation>
<descriptors_generation_software chapter="4.6" help="" name="Software name and version for descriptor generation" options="">				      




<software_ref idref="software_catalog_2" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</descriptors_generation_software>
<descriptors_chemicals_ratio chapter="4.7" help="" name="Descriptors/Chemicals ratio"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      12.7 (38 chemicals/3 descriptors)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_chemicals_ratio>
</QSAR_Algorithm>
<QSAR_Applicability_domain chapter="5" help="" name="Defining the applicability domain - OECD Principle 3">
<app_domain_description chapter="5.1" help="" name="Description of the applicability domain of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Applicability domain based on training set:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      a) by chemical identity: pesticides - amine derivates
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      b)by descriptor value range:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Max electrophilic reactivity index (AM1) (min: 0. 0114, max: 0. 0577)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      RNCS Relative negative charged SA (SAMNEG*RNCG) (AM1) (min: 0, max:13.5)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Reverse Wiener index (min: 96, max: 6550)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_description>
<app_domain_method chapter="5.2" help="" name="Method used to assess the applicability domain"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Pesticides with amine functional groups present in the structures.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Range of descriptor values in training set with &#177;30% confidence.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Descriptor values must fall between maximal and minimal descriptor 
      values of training set &#177;30%.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_method>
<app_domain_software chapter="5.3" help="" name="Software name and version for applicability domain assessment">      




<software_ref idref="software_catalog_3" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</app_domain_software>
<applicability_limits chapter="5.4" help="" name="Limits of applicability"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Compounds should contain amine functional group.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</applicability_limits>
</QSAR_Applicability_domain>

<QSAR_Interpretation chapter="8" help="" name="Providing a mechanistic interpretation - OECD Principle 5">
<mechanistic_basis chapter="8.1" help="" name="Mechanistic basis of the model"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      All the descriptors have negative influence to the property in absolute 
      scale. This means that higher descriptor values lead to structure 
      characteristics that make compounds more toxic. Max electrophilic 
      reactivity index (AM1) is related to LUMO and describes the compound&#8217;s 
      ability to interact with electron pair donors. Electron rich parts of 
      the compounds are described with RNCS Relative negative charged SA 
      (SAMNEG*RNCG) (AM1). In both cases higher values lead to higher toxicity 
      due to stronger interaction contributions to the affinity. Reverse 
      Wiener index describes size and branching of the compound, where 
      branched compound have smaller value than linear ones in magnitude. 
      Thus, the descriptor accounts for the flexibility of the compound. 
      Flexible compounds have higher toxicity because their binding is not as 
      specific as it is for stiff structures.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis>
<mechanistic_basis_comments chapter="8.2" help="" name="A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      A priori - it was postulated that amines have different mechanism than 
      other compounds. The rest of the interpretation &#8211; a posteriori.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_comments>
<mechanistic_basis_info chapter="8.3" help="" name="Other information about the mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_info>
</QSAR_Interpretation>

<QSAR_Endpoint chapter="3" help="" name="Defining the endpoint - OECD Principle 1">
<model_species chapter="3.1" help="" name="Species"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Rabbit
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</model_species>
<model_endpoint chapter="3.2" help="" name="Endpoint">      



<endpoint_ref idref="endpoints_catalog_2" catalog="endpoints_catalog"/>
</model_endpoint>
<endpoint_comments chapter="3.3" help="" name="Comment on endpoint"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Draize rabbit eye test scores, as modified maximum average score (MMAS), 
      for 68
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      pure bulk liquids were adjusted by the liquid-saturated vapor pressure 
      P&#176;. These 68 adjusted scores, as log (MMAS/P&#176;), were shown to be 
      completely equivalent to eye irritation thresholds (EIT), expressed as 
      log (1/EIT), for 23 compounds in humans.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Weighted tissue damage after 21 days exposure.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_comments>
<endpoint_units chapter="3.4" help="" name="Endpoint units"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Modified maximum average score (MMAS) divided by the molarity of the 
      pure liquid 
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_units>
<endpoint_variable chapter="3.5" help="" name="Dependent variable"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      log (MMAS/P&#176;) and log (1/EIT) instead of MMAS/P&#176; and EIT
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (logaritm of the Draize test scores adjusted by the liquid saturated 
      vapor-pressure)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_variable>
<endpoint_protocol chapter="3.6" help="" name="Experimental protocol"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Draize rabbit eye test. The in vivo rabbit eye irritation/corrosion data 
      have been
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      generated since 1981 in studies carried out according to OECD Test 
      Guideline 405 (EU B.5) and following the principles of Good Laboratory 
      Practice. By Draize in vivo rabbit-eye test (Draize et al., 1944), a 
      0.1-ml (or weight equivalent) sample of test substance is placed into 
      the eye. Eye irritation is defined as production of changes in the eye, 
      which are fully reversible within 21 days of application, whereas eye 
      corrosion is defined as production of tissue damage in the eye, or 
      serious physical decay of vision, which is not fully reversible within 
      21 days of application. The tissue grades are combined into a weighted 
      score; the highest average score across test animals is termed the 
      maximum average score (MAS). The modified Draize scores were defined as 
      modified maximum average score (MMAS) divided by the molarity of the 
      pure liquid; the latter is given by 1000 times the density of the pure 
      liquid divided by the liquid molecular weight. The MMAS refer to the 
      effect of pure bulk liquids, whereas the EIT (in ppm) are established 
      from the effect of the vapor of liquids at some particular partial 
      pressure. The MMAS data were selected from European Center for 
      Ecotoxicology and Toxicology of Chemicals databank (ECETOC, 1998).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      References:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      ECETOC manual No. 48(2) (1998). Eye Irritation Reference Chemicals Data 
      Bank, 2nd ed. ECETOC, Brussels.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The EIT data were selected from the article &quot;Quantification of Chemical 
      Vapors in
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Chemosensory Research&quot; published by J. Enrique Cometto-Mu&#241;iz, William S. 
      Cain and Michael H. Abraham in the journal &quot;Chemical senses&quot; 28: 
      467&#8211;477, 2003.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_protocol>
<endpoint_data_quality chapter="3.7" help="" name="Endpoint data quality and variability"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Experimental data from different sources has been validated as 
      consistent ( ref.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      TOXICOLOGICAL SCIENCES 76, 384-391 (2003) )
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Statistics:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      -the experimental results have been obtained using Draize test scores 
      for 68 compounds
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (several sources but highly standardized procedure) and EIT (Eye 
      Irritation Threshold)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      for 23 compounds.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The Draize test scores and EIT can be compared as
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (log(MMAS/P0)=log(1/EIT) +m&#8217;&#8217;).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      max value: 2.37
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      min value: -5.24
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      standard deviation: 1.538
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      skewness: 0.886
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_data_quality>
</QSAR_Endpoint>
<QSAR_Algorithm chapter="4" help="" name="Defining the algorithm - OECD Principle 2">
<algorithm_type chapter="4.1" help="" name="Type of model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      2D and 3D regression-based QSAR Multilinear regression model based on 
      3-D quantum chemical descriptors.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</algorithm_type>
<algorithm_explicit chapter="4.2" help="" name="Explicit algorithm">
<algorithm_ref idref="algorithms_catalog_3" catalog="algorithms_catalog"/>
<equation/>
</algorithm_explicit>
<algorithms_descriptors chapter="4.3" help="" name="Descriptors in the model">            














<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_1" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_2" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_3" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_4" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
</algorithms_descriptors>
<descriptors_selection chapter="4.4" help="" name="Descriptor selection"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Initial pool of ~1000 descriptors. Stepwise descriptor selection based 
      on a set of statistical selection rules (1-parameter equations: Fisher 
      criterion and , R2 over threshold, variance and  t-test value over 
      threshold, intercorrelation with another descriptor not over treshold),
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (2 parameter equations: intercorrelation coefficient below threshold, , 
      significant correlation with endpoint, In terms of correlation 
      coefficient and t-test)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Stepwise trial of additional descriptors not significantly correlated to 
      any already in the model.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_selection>
<descriptors_generation chapter="4.5" help="" name="Algorithm and descriptor generation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1D, 2D, and 3D theoretical calculations
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      quantum chemical descriptors derived from MMFFs(vacuum) AM1 calculation. 
      Model developed by using multilinear regression.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_generation>
<descriptors_generation_software chapter="4.6" help="" name="Software name and version for descriptor generation" options="">				      





<software_ref idref="software_catalog_2" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</descriptors_generation_software>
<descriptors_chemicals_ratio chapter="4.7" help="" name="Descriptors/Chemicals ratio"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      0.055
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_chemicals_ratio>
</QSAR_Algorithm>
<QSAR_Applicability_domain chapter="5" help="" name="Defining the applicability domain - OECD Principle 3">
<app_domain_description chapter="5.1" help="" name="Description of the applicability domain of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Applicability domain based on training set:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      By chemical identity: Organic liquids (diverse set of aromatic, cyclic 
      and aliphatic alcohols, esters, halogeno compounds, ketones).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      By descriptor value range: The model is suitable for compounds that have 
      the descriptors
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      in the following range: Gravitation index(all bonds)(AM1) (min: 213.606, 
      max: 2497.675),
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      HASA- 1/TMSA(AM1)(min: 0, max: 0.318), Lowest e-e repulsion (1-center) 
      (AM1)(min:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1.296, max: 3.543), Max nucleophilic reactivity index (AM1) for C atoms 
      (0.002,
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      0.052).
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_description>
<app_domain_method chapter="5.2" help="" name="Method used to assess the applicability domain"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      presence of functional groups in structures
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Range of descriptor values in training set with &#177;30% confidence
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Descriptor values must fall between maximal and minimal descriptor 
      values of training set &#177;30%.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_method>
<app_domain_software chapter="5.3" help="" name="Software name and version for applicability domain assessment">      





<software_ref idref="software_catalog_3" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</app_domain_software>
<applicability_limits chapter="5.4" help="" name="Limits of applicability"><html>
  <head>

      Nothing given

</applicability_limits>
</QSAR_Applicability_domain>

<QSAR_Interpretation chapter="8" help="" name="Providing a mechanistic interpretation - OECD Principle 5">
<mechanistic_basis chapter="8.1" help="" name="Mechanistic basis of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      According to the model equation, eye irritation depends on the hydrogen 
      bond
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      donor and acceptor capabilities of a liquid as well as on the the 
      overall shape and bulkiness. The key issue is the transport from eye 
      surface into the biophase, binding to the phospholipid membrane and 
      possible binding to the receptor.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis>
<mechanistic_basis_comments chapter="8.2" help="" name="A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      a posteriori mechanistic interpretation, consistent with published 
      scientific interpretations of experiments.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_comments>
<mechanistic_basis_info chapter="8.3" help="" name="Other information about the mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The descriptor HASA-1/TMSA (AM1) reflects transfer of the compounds to a 
      phase characterized by hydrogen bonding and descriptors Lowest e-e 
      repulsion (1-center) (AM1) for C atoms reflect the transfer of the 
      compounds to a phase that is quite polar and hydrophobic.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The proposed mechanism based on the model agrees well with literature: 
      TOXICOLOGICAL SCIENCES 76, 384-391 (2003)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_info>
</QSAR_Interpretation>
<QSAR_Miscelaneous chapter="9" help="" name="Miscellaneous information">

<QSAR_Endpoint chapter="3" help="" name="Defining the endpoint - OECD Principle 1">
<model_species chapter="3.1" help="" name="Species"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Rabbit
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</model_species>
<model_endpoint chapter="3.2" help="" name="Endpoint">      



<endpoint_ref idref="endpoints_catalog_2" catalog="endpoints_catalog"/>
</model_endpoint>
<endpoint_comments chapter="3.3" help="" name="Comment on endpoint"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Draize rabbit eye test scores, as modified maximum average score (MMAS), 
      for 68
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      pure bulk liquids were adjusted by the liquid-saturated vapor pressure 
      P&#176;. These 68 adjusted scores, as log (MMAS/P&#176;), were shown to be 
      completely equivalent to eye irritation thresholds (EIT), expressed as 
      log (1/EIT), for 23 compounds in humans.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Weighted tissue damage after 21 days exposure.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_comments>
<endpoint_units chapter="3.4" help="" name="Endpoint units"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Modified maximum average score (MMAS) divided by the molarity of the 
      pure liquid 
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_units>
<endpoint_variable chapter="3.5" help="" name="Dependent variable"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      log (MMAS/P&#176;) and log (1/EIT) instead of MMAS/P&#176; and EIT
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (logaritm of the Draize test scores adjusted by the liquid saturated 
      vapor-pressure)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_variable>
<endpoint_protocol chapter="3.6" help="" name="Experimental protocol"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Draize rabbit eye test. The in vivo rabbit eye irritation/corrosion data 
      have been
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      generated since 1981 in studies carried out according to OECD Test 
      Guideline 405 (EU B.5) and following the principles of Good Laboratory 
      Practice. By Draize in vivo rabbit-eye test (Draize et al., 1944), a 
      0.1-ml (or weight equivalent) sample of test substance is placed into 
      the eye. Eye irritation is defined as production of changes in the eye, 
      which are fully reversible within 21 days of application, whereas eye 
      corrosion is defined as production of tissue damage in the eye, or 
      serious physical decay of vision, which is not fully reversible within 
      21 days of application. The tissue grades are combined into a weighted 
      score; the highest average score across test animals is termed the 
      maximum average score (MAS). The modified Draize scores were defined as 
      modified maximum average score (MMAS) divided by the molarity of the 
      pure liquid; the latter is given by 1000 times the density of the pure 
      liquid divided by the liquid molecular weight. The MMAS refer to the 
      effect of pure bulk liquids, whereas the EIT (in ppm) are established 
      from the effect of the vapor of liquids at some particular partial 
      pressure. The MMAS data were selected from European Center for 
      Ecotoxicology and Toxicology of Chemicals databank (ECETOC, 1998).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      References:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      ECETOC manual No. 48(2) (1998). Eye Irritation Reference Chemicals Data 
      Bank, 2nd ed. ECETOC, Brussels.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The EIT data were selected from the article &quot;Quantification of Chemical 
      Vapors in
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Chemosensory Research&quot; published by J. Enrique Cometto-Mu&#241;iz, William S. 
      Cain and Michael H. Abraham in the journal &quot;Chemical senses&quot; 28: 
      467&#8211;477, 2003.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_protocol>
<endpoint_data_quality chapter="3.7" help="" name="Endpoint data quality and variability"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Experimental data from different sources has been validated as 
      consistent ( ref.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      TOXICOLOGICAL SCIENCES 76, 384-391 (2003) )
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Statistics:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      -the experimental results have been obtained using Draize test scores 
      for 68 compounds
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (several sources but highly standardized procedure) and EIT (Eye 
      Irritation Threshold)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      for 23 compounds.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The Draize test scores and EIT can be compared as
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (log(MMAS/P0)=log(1/EIT) +m&#8217;&#8217;).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      max value: 2.37
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      min value: -5.24
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      standard deviation: 1.538
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      skewness: 0.886
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</endpoint_data_quality>
</QSAR_Endpoint>
<QSAR_Algorithm chapter="4" help="" name="Defining the algorithm - OECD Principle 2">
<algorithm_type chapter="4.1" help="" name="Type of model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      2D and 3D regression-based QSAR Multilinear regression model based on 
      3-D quantum chemical descriptors.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</algorithm_type>
<algorithm_explicit chapter="4.2" help="" name="Explicit algorithm">
<algorithm_ref idref="algorithms_catalog_3" catalog="algorithms_catalog"/>
<equation/>
</algorithm_explicit>
<algorithms_descriptors chapter="4.3" help="" name="Descriptors in the model">            














<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_1" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_2" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_3" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
<descriptor_ref idref="descriptors_catalog_4" catalog="descriptors_catalog"/>
</algorithms_descriptors>
<descriptors_selection chapter="4.4" help="" name="Descriptor selection"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Initial pool of ~1000 descriptors. Stepwise descriptor selection based 
      on a set of statistical selection rules (1-parameter equations: Fisher 
      criterion and , R2 over threshold, variance and  t-test value over 
      threshold, intercorrelation with another descriptor not over treshold),
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      (2 parameter equations: intercorrelation coefficient below threshold, , 
      significant correlation with endpoint, In terms of correlation 
      coefficient and t-test)
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Stepwise trial of additional descriptors not significantly correlated to 
      any already in the model.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_selection>
<descriptors_generation chapter="4.5" help="" name="Algorithm and descriptor generation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1D, 2D, and 3D theoretical calculations
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      quantum chemical descriptors derived from MMFFs(vacuum) AM1 calculation. 
      Model developed by using multilinear regression.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_generation>
<descriptors_generation_software chapter="4.6" help="" name="Software name and version for descriptor generation" options="">				      





<software_ref idref="software_catalog_2" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</descriptors_generation_software>
<descriptors_chemicals_ratio chapter="4.7" help="" name="Descriptors/Chemicals ratio"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      0.055
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</descriptors_chemicals_ratio>
</QSAR_Algorithm>
<QSAR_Applicability_domain chapter="5" help="" name="Defining the applicability domain - OECD Principle 3">
<app_domain_description chapter="5.1" help="" name="Description of the applicability domain of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Applicability domain based on training set:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      By chemical identity: Organic liquids (diverse set of aromatic, cyclic 
      and aliphatic alcohols, esters, halogeno compounds, ketones).
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      By descriptor value range: The model is suitable for compounds that have 
      the descriptors
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      in the following range: Gravitation index(all bonds)(AM1) (min: 213.606, 
      max: 2497.675),
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      HASA- 1/TMSA(AM1)(min: 0, max: 0.318), Lowest e-e repulsion (1-center) 
      (AM1)(min:
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      1.296, max: 3.543), Max nucleophilic reactivity index (AM1) for C atoms 
      (0.002,
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      0.052).
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_description>
<app_domain_method chapter="5.2" help="" name="Method used to assess the applicability domain"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      presence of functional groups in structures
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Range of descriptor values in training set with &#177;30% confidence
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Descriptor values must fall between maximal and minimal descriptor 
      values of training set &#177;30%.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</app_domain_method>
<app_domain_software chapter="5.3" help="" name="Software name and version for applicability domain assessment">      





<software_ref idref="software_catalog_3" catalog="software_catalog"/>
</app_domain_software>

</applicability_limits>
</QSAR_Applicability_domain>

      R2 = 0.802
    </p>
  </body>
</html>

<QSAR_Interpretation chapter="8" help="" name="Providing a mechanistic interpretation - OECD Principle 5">
<mechanistic_basis chapter="8.1" help="" name="Mechanistic basis of the model"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      According to the model equation, eye irritation depends on the hydrogen 
      bond
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      donor and acceptor capabilities of a liquid as well as on the the 
      overall shape and bulkiness. The key issue is the transport from eye 
      surface into the biophase, binding to the phospholipid membrane and 
      possible binding to the receptor.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis>
<mechanistic_basis_comments chapter="8.2" help="" name="A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>

  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      a posteriori mechanistic interpretation, consistent with published 
      scientific interpretations of experiments.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_comments>
<mechanistic_basis_info chapter="8.3" help="" name="Other information about the mechanistic interpretation"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The descriptor HASA-1/TMSA (AM1) reflects transfer of the compounds to a 
      phase characterized by hydrogen bonding and descriptors Lowest e-e 
      repulsion (1-center) (AM1) for C atoms reflect the transfer of the 
      compounds to a phase that is quite polar and hydrophobic.
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      The proposed mechanism based on the model agrees well with literature: 
      TOXICOLOGICAL SCIENCES 76, 384-391 (2003)
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</mechanistic_basis_info>
</QSAR_Interpretation>
<QSAR_Miscelaneous chapter="9" help="" name="Miscellaneous information">
<comments chapter="9.1" help="" name="Comments"><html>
  <head>
    
  </head>
  <body>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      Draize rabbit eye test scores, as modified maximum average score (MMAS), 
      for 68
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      pure bulk liquids were adjusted by the liquid-saturated vapor pressure 
      P&#176;. These 68 adjusted
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      scores, as log (MMAS/P&#176;), were shown to be completely equivalent to eye 
      irritation
    </p>
    <p style="margin-top: 0">
      thresholds (EIT), expressed as log (1/EIT), for 23 compounds in humans.
    </p>
  </body>
</html>
</comments>
